summary: This is a transcript of a voluntary sworn interview conducted by the DOJ Office of the Inspector General with a former BOP Captain at MCC New York regarding the circumstances surrounding the death of Jeffrey Epstein. The interview focuses on security protocols, staffing, cell assignments, and potential failures in supervision and documentation leading up to Epstein's death on August 10, 2019.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: High-profile inmate found deceased in his cell at MCC on August 10, 2019. The interview discusses his housing, behavior, and supervision.

persons.name: Nicholas Tartaglione
persons.context: Former police officer and inmate who was Epstein's cell mate during a prior incident where Epstein was found unresponsive. Epstein accused him of trying to kill him, which was deemed not credible.

persons.name: Efrain Reyes
persons.context: Inmate selected and vetted to be Epstein's cell mate. He was released from court on August 9, 2019, leaving Epstein without a cell mate.

persons.name: Joaquin Guzman
persons.context: Notorious inmate (drug kingpin) housed in the Ten South Special Management Unit at MCC, mentioned as an example of a high-security inmate.

persons.name: Tova Noel
persons.context: Correctional Officer assigned to the SHU on the morning watch shift when Epstein was found deceased. Admitted to not conducting rounds and counts.

persons.name: Michael Thomas
persons.context: Non-custody staff member (Material Handler) working overtime in the SHU on the morning watch shift. Entered Epstein's cell without supervision when he was found unresponsive.

connections.description: Were cell mates in the SHU. Epstein accused Tartaglione of trying to kill him during an incident on July 23, 2019, which was investigated and deemed not credible.
Reyes was the vetted cell mate assigned to Epstein after the Tartaglione incident. Reyes was released from court on August 9, 2019, leaving Epstein without a cell mate.
Both were assigned to the SHU on the morning watch shift of August 10, 2019. They admitted to not conducting required rounds and counts.

events.title: Epstein found unresponsive with homemade fabric
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive on the floor of his cell with a homemade piece of fabric on his chest. His cell mate, Nicholas Tartaglione, alerted staff. Epstein claimed Tartaglione tried to kill him, but the investigation found the claim not credible and suggested Epstein was engaging in manipulative behavior.

events.title: Efrain Reyes released from court
events.description: Inmate Efrain Reyes, Epstein's vetted cell mate, went to court and was released, not returning to MCC. This left Epstein without a cell mate, a violation of protocols. The SHU staff failed to properly report or address this.

events.title: Jeffrey Epstein found deceased
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell at MCC New York in the early morning hours. He was pronounced dead. The interview reveals multiple protocol failures leading up to this event, including failure to conduct counts and rounds, and Epstein being without a cell mate.

events.title: OIG Interview with former MCC Captain
events.description: The DOJ OIG conducts a voluntary sworn interview with a former BOP Captain from MCC regarding the circumstances of Jeffrey Epstein's death, focusing on security failures and staff performance.

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC), 150 Park Row, New York, New York
FCI Fort Dix, New Jersey (location of interview)
Ten South (Special Management Unit) at MCC
keyFacts: Epstein was not in his assigned cell for six days prior to his death; inmate movement paperwork was not properly updated in the system.
Epstein's SHU inmate file was found to be empty when secured after his death, suggesting documents may have been purposefully removed.
Required counts at 4:00 p.m., 10:00 p.m., 12:00 a.m., 3:00 a.m., and 5:00 a.m. on August 9-10, 2019, were not conducted, and count slips were falsified.
SHU staff Tova Noel and Michael Thomas admitted to not conducting 30-minute rounds and were observed sleeping on camera footage.
The camera system in the SHU was reportedly down, and the Captain was not properly notified of this security issue.
